67606.title: bonnet (calash)
67606.description: Emerald green lightweight silk calash bonnet is hand-stitched, has 6 collapsible ruffles, a pair of neck-ties for the front closure, and an inner drawstring on the back of the neck.  There is a bow-tie decorating the back of the bonnet.  There does appear to be some wear to the bonnet, as some of the fabric is worn through on the inside, possibly due to moth damage.  The outside is in better shape with some worn spots on the straw caning.  It measures 14" from the back of the bonnet to the face opening.
67606.provenance: Internet seller "juicesm3"; purchased online by Amy Davidoff, Indianapolis and Cincinnati, in 2003; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2009.

28780.title: hat
28780.creation_notes: Aitken Sons & Co. Broadway & 18th St. NYC
28780.description: velvet pansies, silk flowers and lace trim with long velvet ribbons hanging down
28780.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Erwin C. Stout
28780.provenance: Mrs. Erwin Stout, Indianapolis; given to Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1975.
28780.inscription: Aitken Sons & Co., Broadway & 18th St. NYC

extended_text.content:
By the early 1870s, bonnets had been replaced by hats. Fashions changed rapidly over the next three decades and many new hat styles were created.

Toques (small, close fitting, brimless hats) and hats with velvet ribbon streamers suspended from the back were worn by fashionable women of the time.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

28780.exhibit_history:
Hats Off
Paul Textile Gallery, Indianapolis Museum of Art
April 24- October 23, 1999.
